--- In neat=
@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> Peter, sounds=
 like a fascinating experiment!  Like others, I'd love 
> to see examples o=
f what you describe in some kind of video!  
Perhaps 
> you can upload it t=
o YouTube :)  
> 
> The idea that the HyperNEAT-evolved solution looks more=
 "natural" 
is 
> very interesting, as is your chosen substrate configurati=
on and how 
> it gives the system an opportunity to utilize the body geomet=
ry.
> 
> ken

> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" 
> =
<petar_chervenski@> wrote:
> >
> > Hello there, 
> > 
> > I am using the fo=
llowing CPPN model for the substrate: 
> > 
> > Inputs: X1, Y1, X2, Y2, BIA=
S
> > Outputs: Weight, Node-Bias, Node-Time_Constant
> > 
> > The time cons=
tant range is [0.5 .. 5.0] and the weight/node-bias 
> range 
> > within th=
e substrate in [-8.0 .. 8.0]. 
> > The weight range in the CPPN is unbounde=
d. 
> > 
> > The node-specific outputs are computed using (X1, Y1, BIAS) an=
d 
> the 
> > others set to 0.
> > 
> > The activation functions used are p=
lain sigmoid, gaussian, and 
> sine. 
> > The CTRNN substrate activates wit=
h 0.02 timestep and it is used 
to 
> > control a 3D humanoid model, simula=
ted in a physical environment 
> (using 
> > Open Dynamics Engine http://ww=
w.ode.org ). 
> > 
> > The thing I notice, is the following: 
> > 
> > The =
first networks are simple, and so the connective patterns 
are. 
> But 
> >=
 the node biases and time constants are also simple. When I watch 
> an 
> =
> animaion of the activation changing in the substrate, it looks 
> like it=
 
> > exibits a pattern. The simplest I've seen can be described as a 
> me=
xican 
> > wave travelling across the hidden nodes. 
> > As the CPPNs compl=
exify, so do the activity patterns exibited. 
> When 
> > using regular NEA=
T for the problem of keeping the humanoid model 
> > balanced, it has moslt=
y erratic behaviour, and the lucky ones 
> (with 
> > high fitness) usually=
 find a way to trick the system and stay in 
a 
> > balanced position forev=
er, without moving at all. 
> > But when HyperNEAT is used for this, it loo=
ks really interesting 
> and.. 
> > natural! The model is trying to balance=
 using its arms, and it is 
> > moving.. It looks like a drunk guy, but you=
 note the difference. 
> > I've arranged the nodes in a geometric way.. Let=
 me explain - the 
> left 
> > and right arm's outputs are separated in the=
 left and right in 
the 
> > substrate space, and close to each other. So d=
o the legs. The 
> hidden 
> > nodes are in the center in a star/cirlular s=
hape. I also included 
> 3 
> > inputs (head velocity) in the center around=
 0.0, but with smaller 
> > radius than the ring of hidden nodes. 
> > 
> >=
 Peter
> >
>
